title: shooting03
text:
(0) Comments 
Madison — An outspoken Wisconsin lawmaker said Friday that this week's shooting at an Oregon community college happened in a "gun-free zone," leaving out the fact that at least one student at the college was armed at the time of the shooting and sought to protect his fellow students. 
Wisconsin Rep. Bob Gannon (R-Slinger) said that he had based his statements on media accounts and the student handbook of Umpqua Community College, which he said discouraged students from carrying firearms. 
"The first media reports made it that it was a gun-free zone," Gannon said. "So drop it, that's not the story." 
In 2011, the Oregon Court of Appeals ruled that that state's public university system could not prohibit students with concealed carry permits from carrying firearms on campus grounds. That state's higher education board has sought to ban students from carrying them inside buildings. 
Gannon was responding to President Barack Obama's statements in favor of gun control in the wake of the shooting at Umpqua, where at least 10 people were killed including the 26-year-old gunman, Christopher Sean Harper-Mercer . 
"What Obama ignored was the testimony of the students and educators at the school that they were defenseless in this incident as the school was a 'gun free' zone. This means that only criminals will possess personal protection at these locations, and the law abiding citizen is an easy target," a statement released by Gannon's office said. 
In an email, Gannon, who has a concealed carry permit, said he has told those around him on the Assembly floor that "if shooting starts, they should hit the floor, because I have every intention of defending myself." 
In an interview Thursday with MSNBC , an Umpqua student and veteran with a concealed carry permit, John Parker, Jr., said he considered intervening during the shooting but decided to stay in a classroom to guard other students and staff. 
"I was prepared to defend the classroom," Parker said. © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Jason Stein 
Jason Stein covers the state Capitol and is the author with his colleague Patrick Marley of "More than They Bargained For: Scott Walker, Unions and the Fight for Wisconsin." His work has been recognized by journalism groups such as the American Society of News Editors, the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, and the Association of Capitol Reporters and Editors.
